Award.AwardTitle: High Speed Distributed Optical Fiber Sensing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to explore the signal group delay induced by chromatic dispersion in optical fibers and its application in long-span, high speed distributed fiber optic sensing. The approach will be to multiplex a large number of identical weak reflecting fiber Bragg gratings in a single optical fiber and to interrogate them with a fast spectrum-to-time conversion method. This dynamic spectrum characterization to a delay-time measurement circumvents the requirements of heavy averaging and dynamic spectral analysis as encountered in the current distributed fiber sensor products. The thermal stability of the ultra-weak gratings used in the system will be investigated for their improved performance at high temperatures.

If successful, the benefits of this research will include dynamic health monitoring of many civil and industrial structures and systems and low cost seismological oil and gas exploration. This technology may also be useful to earth quake detection and volcano activity monitoring. The multidisciplinary nature of the research will offer balanced training for the participating students, enrich the current photonics curriculum at Virginia Tech and promote the involvement of students from underrepresented minority groups in the scientific and engineering research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We proposed a technology to demonstrate long-range and high-speed quasi-distributed fiber optic sensing for strain or temperature. It was based on multiplexation of UW-FBGs and utilization of dispersive elements. The idea was to convert the wavelength shift of the FBGs to time-delay variation so that the wavelength shift of the FBGs could be measured indirectly without knowing their spectra.

We built a light source required by this system using a superluminescent diode (SLD), a semiconductor optical amplifier (SOA)-based optical shutter and erbium doped fiber amplifier (EDFA). The output pulses had repetition rate of 20 kHz, spectral bandwidth of 6 nm, temporal width of 2 ns and peak power of 2 W. All these parameters were tunable so the light source could be adjusted for different requirements.

A dispersive unit with total dispersion of -2783ps/nm was built using dispersion-compensating fiber (DCF) in one arm of a Mach-Zehnder structure and single mode fiber (SMF) in the other. A modified structure was later proposed and built to increase the sensing speed and power utilization. This modified dispersive unit required two detectors instead of one but could double the sensing speed while maintaining the same sensing range. It also increased the power arriving at the photodetector by 3 dB.  

Algorithms were modified to achieve better resolution. Instead of using interpolation before performing cross-correlation, parabolic curve fitting was applied afterwards. This change reduced the amount of data required in signal processing and the standard of measured strain or temperature to half of the previous value (Figure 1).

The influence of several key factors (signal to noise ratio (SNR), pulse width, total dispersion and sampling interval) were simulated and the results showed that higher SNR, narrower pulse, higher dispersion and smaller sampling interval were preferred to have better resolution for measurements.  SNR had the most significant influence(Figure 2).

The limitation of sensing speed and spatial resolution were also analyzed. Theoretically the sensing speed is determined by the sensing range, based on the requirement that the returned pulses from two consecutive measurements should not overlap. The spatial resolution was determined by the maximum time-delay expected by the application and the pulse width, based on the requirement that the two pulse from adjacent FBGs should not overlap, even under extreme environment conditions.

In a proof-of-concept demonstration, static responses to strain were measured, and linear and repeatable responses were observed. The conversion factor was measured to be -3.37 ps/με. A digital filter was applied to significantly increase the performance. This work was published on EL[1].

Using the previously-built light source and dispersive unit, the dynamic response of a sensing link 2014 UW-FBGs was measured at 20 kHz. The reflectance was -35 dB and the spacing between FBGs was 1 m. The standard deviation of wavelength was measured to be 9.03 pm without averaging, and this number could be reduced to 2.90 pm if the data was averaged 10 times. Dynamic response was also measured under this condition and the resolution was 0.3pm/Hz^(1/2). This part of the work has been published in PTL. See the attached Figure 3.

A systematic noise analysis and corresponding measurements were also carried out to confirm that the main noise sources were Rayleigh backscattering and optical amplification. Methods for extending the sensing range and increasing the performance were also proposed.

[1] Lingmei Ma, Cheng Ma, Yunmiao Wang, Dorothy Y. Wang, Anbo Wang, “High-Speed Quasi-Distributed Strain Sensing Based on Time Division Multiplexing of Fibre Bragg Gratings”, Electronics Letters, Vol. 52, No. 8, p. 643 – 645 April, 2016.

[2] Lingmei Ma, Cheng Ma, Yunmiao Wang, Dorothy Y. Wang, Anbo Wang, “High Speed Distributed Sensing based on Ultra Weak FBGs and Chromatic Dispersion”, IEEE Photonics Technology Letters , Vol. 28, No. 12, p. 1344 – 1347, April, 2016
